events.title: Signing of the United States Constitution
events.description: The United States Constitution was signed by delegates at the Constitutional Convention in Philadelphia, marking the establishment of the framework of the federal government of the United States.
events.significance: It laid the foundational legal structure for the United States, influencing democratic governance worldwide.

events.title: Battle of Antietam
events.description: The Battle of Antietam during the American Civil War became the bloodiest single-day battle in American history with about 22,700 casualties.
events.significance: This battle halted the Confederate advance into the North and gave President Abraham Lincoln the opportunity to issue the Emancipation Proclamation.

events.title: Soviet Union invades Poland
events.description: Following the Molotov-Ribbentrop Pact, the Soviet Union invaded eastern Poland, expanding the conflict of World War II.
events.significance: This invasion contributed to the division of Poland between Germany and the Soviet Union, escalating World War II.

events.title: First Women's Day at the US Open
events.description: Chris Evert and Billie Jean King fought the first officially designated Women's Day at the US Open tennis tournament.
events.significance: This event marked a milestone in women's sports, promoting gender equality in tennis and sports in general.

events.title: Rome Declaration signed
events.description: Representatives from 27 European Union countries signed the Rome Declaration commemorating the 60th anniversary of the Treaty of Rome.
events.significance: The declaration reaffirmed commitment to a united Europe amidst growing challenges to unity.
